questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of nocturia and a weak urinary stream. These symptoms began 1 year ago, but have progressively worsened over the past 6 months. He now wakes up 3–5 times every night to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. The patient has smoked a half-pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He appears well. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 128/77 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender. Digital rectal examination shows a diffusely enlarged prostate with a firm, nontender nodule in the right posterior lobe. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is 6.5 ng/mL (N< 4). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measure PSA level again in 2 years
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urethrocystoscopy may be used to evaluate patients with hematuria for urothelial cancer. Urethrocystoscopy is also used in the diagnosis and treatment of urethral strictures in patients with voiding symptoms (e.g., weak urinary stream). However, prostate malignancy must be ruled out before the procedure, especially in the presence of elevated PSA levels and suspicious findings on DRE.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the PSA level again in 2 years is appropriate in patients enrolled in prostate cancer screening after a normal PSA test. This patient's clinical findings and PSA level are consistent with prostate cancer, making another step in management more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is indicated to confirm or rule out prostate cancer in patients with a life expectancy > 10 years and suspicious findings on DRE, elevated PSA levels, or clinical suspicion. This procedure involves the collection of 12 tissue samples from different areas of the prostate, guided by transrectal ultrasonography under local anesthesia and prophylactic antibiotics. If prostate cancer is confirmed via biopsy, the tumor is graded based on microscopic appearance using the Gleason score. Some guidelines recommend obtaining a multiparametric MRI of the prostate prior to biopsy.

To guide management in patients with intermediate or high-risk prostate cancer, cross-sectional imaging (CT, MRI, or PET-CT scan) is recommended to evaluate local tumor extent, lymph node involvement, and metastasis.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis can be used to assess for extraprostatic extension, liver metastasis, and urinary obstruction in patients with prostate cancer. While this patient's clinical presentation, examination findings, and PSA level are highly suspicious for prostate malignancy, the diagnosis has yet to be confirmed.

E) INCORRECT:

Simple prostatectomy is mainly performed in patients with very large prostates (> 75 g) due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). While DRE in patients with BPH usually shows a diffusely enlarged prostate, the presence of a firm nodule would be uncommon.

F) INCORRECT:

Since prostate cancer most frequently metastasizes to the bone, spinal x-ray and scintigraphy with technetium-99m are indicated for staging purposes. Although this patient has characteristic features of prostate malignancy, the diagnosis must first be confirmed.
questions.hint: This patient presents with lower urinary tract symptoms (nocturia and a weak urinary stream), a hard, nontender nodule on digital rectal examination (DRE), and an elevated PSA level, all of which raise suspicion for prostate cancer.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his lower extremities and urinary incontinence for the past 2 weeks. Over the past 2 months, he has had increasing back pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 106/60 mm Hg. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Muscle strength is decreased in bilateral lower extremities. Sensation to pain and temperature and position sense are absent in the buttocks, perineum, and lower extremities. Ankle clonus is present. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. An x-ray of the spine shows multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Bence Jones protein in the urine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A left testicular mass suggests testicular cancer. Although metastatic testicular cancer may cause spinal cord compression, it manifests with a mix of osteolytic and osteoblastic lesions rather than osteoblastic lesions alone. In this age group (> 60 years), lymphomas are the most common neoplasm of the testes, rather than primary testicular cancers. While metastatic lymphoma can manifest with sclerotic, lytic, or mixed bone lesions, another tumor entity is much more likely to be responsible for this patient's sclerotic bone lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

An irregular, asymmetric mole could be a malignant melanoma. Although malignant melanoma may manifest with bone metastasis, causing spinal cord compression, this disease would cause osteolytic lesions rather than osteoblastic ones.

C) INCORRECT:

An enlarged thyroid lobe may indicate thyroid cancer. Although thyroid cancer may cause vertebral metastases, this condition manifests with osteolytic instead of osteoblastic lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen may suggest colon cancer. Although colon cancer can metastasize to the bones and manifest with osteoblastic metastases, this outcome is not a frequent finding (seen in only 5–10% of cases of advanced colorectal cancer). Instead, the liver and lung (in that order) are the most common sites of metastases in colorectal carcinoma. The absence of symptoms associated with colorectal cancer, such as a change in bowel habits, melena or hematochezia, signs of anemia, and/or weight loss, make colon cancer unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Bence Jones protein in the urine suggests multiple myeloma (MM). This malignancy is the most common primary tumor of the spine and may manifest with spinal cord compression. However, MM causes osteolytic rather than osteoblastic lesions. Furthermore, while MM is often asymptomatic, advanced disease, which is suggested by this patient's multiple bone lesions, is likely to manifest with symptoms of anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue), leukopenia (e.g, increased susceptibility to infections), or hypercalcemia (e.g., abdominal pain).
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

F) CORRECT:

The combination of this patient's male sex, advanced age (> 50 years), and osteoblastic bone lesions strongly suggests prostate cancer, in which elevated prostate-specific antigen levels are expected. Advanced-stage prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to the spine, causing spinal cord compression and predominantly osteoblastic lesions (osteolytic lesions may occur but are rare). Prostate cancer is the most common cause of osteoblastic metastases, which manifest with increased density and sclerotic appearance on x-ray.

In most patients with metastatic prostate cancer, the digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals asymmetric areas, indurations, or frank nodules within the prostate, but the absence of findings on DRE alone does not exclude prostate cancer.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen and pelvis (AP view) of a patient with prostate cancer

Multiple sclerotic lesions are present throughout the lumbar spine, pelvis, and proximal femurs (overlay).

Sclerotic (osteoblastic) bone metastases are less common than osteolytic metastases. They are seen with prostate, breast, bladder (transitional cell), and bowel (mucinous) cancers, neuroendocrine tumors, and lymphoma.
questions.hint: The presence of back pain, urinary incontinence, and progressive muscle weakness with ankle clonus as well as decreased sensation over the lower extremities are indicative of spinal cord compression. The sclerotic lesions on x-ray suggest osteoblastic metastases.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening back pain that wakes him up at night. He also reports symptoms of urinary urgency and a weak urine stream. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Rectal examination shows an enlarged and hardened prostate with a nodular surface. After further evaluation and confirmation of the diagnosis, he is started on a new drug. Initially, there is an increase in serum testosterone and dihydrotestosterone levels, followed by a sustained decrease in both serum hormone levels. Treatment with which of the following drugs was most likely initiated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Leuprolide is a long-acting GnRH agonist that is commonly used to treat androgen-sensitive prostate cancer. When administered continuously, it causes downregulation of the GnRH receptor in the pituitary, with a subsequent decrease in FSH and LH secretion. This manifests as an initial increase in serum testosterone and dihydrotestosterone levels during the first few weeks of therapy, secondary to transiently increased gonadotropins, followed by a sustained decrease in both hormones.

The initial increase in serum testosterone and dihydrotestosterone may stimulate prostate cancer growth and, as a consequence, worsen symptoms. To prevent a transient flare of prostate cancer-related symptoms, GnRH agonists are usually combined with antiandrogens like flutamide or bicalutamide, which counteract the effects of elevated androgen levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogenic drug that competitively inhibits testosterone and dihydrotestosterone binding at the androgen-receptor complex. Flutamide would be expected to cause a sustained increase in the serum testosterone level, due to the inhibition of the negative feedback of testosterone on the hypothalamus and pituitary. This patient's initial increase and subsequent decrease of testosterone is not consistent with flutamide use.

C) INCORRECT:

Finasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) and is commonly used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia and androgenic alopecia. Lower levels of DHT leads to decreased prostatic growth and increased prostatic apoptosis. The use of finasteride could cause an increase in serum testosterone levels (because it causes less testosterone to be converted to DHT), but it would not explain the concurrent increase in DHT seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that inhibits adrenal androgen synthesis and has direct cytotoxic effects on prostate cancer cells. However, it would not cause an initial increase in the levels of serum testosterone and dihydrotestosterone, as seen in this patient. In fact, serum testosterone levels would decline rapidly within the first 24 hours of initiating the therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyproterone acetate is a steroidal antiandrogenic drug that inhibits binding of dihydrotestosterone to the androgen receptor as well as LH secretion. It is used as a palliative treatment in patients with advanced prostate cancer. It would cause a decrease in testosterone levels (due to LH inhibition), without the initial increase seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that is used to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Anastrozole may cause an increase in serum testosterone (due to decreased conversion to estradiol) but would not be expected to cause a sustained decrease. Additionally, this patient, who has prostate cancer, does not have any indications for anastrozole therapy.
questions.hint: When administered continuously, this drug can be used in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer. When administered in a pulsatile fashion, it can be used to treat infertility in women.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. Six years ago, he underwent a colonoscopy, which was unremarkable. He has no history of serious illness except for an episode of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis at the age of 10 years. His father died of bladder carcinoma at the age of 55 years and his brother was diagnosed with prostate cancer at the age of 61 years. The patient works at a rubber factory. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 12 years. He drinks 1–2 cans of beer per day. He takes no medications. His vaccinations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks what additional health maintenance measures he should consider at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Discuss prostate-specific antigen assessment with the patient
Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology can be used in the workup for urothelial cancer. While this patient has risk factors for bladder cancer (works at a rubber factory, family history of bladder cancer, smokes cigarettes), urine cytology is not used for routine screening of bladder cancer because of its low sensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

The US Preventative Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 6 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

C) CORRECT:

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement may be considered as part of the screening process for prostate cancer, a common malignancy that is often asymptomatic in the initial stages. Current screening guidelines for prostate-specific antigen testing are controversial. The use of PSA as a screening marker is constantly questioned because of potential overdiagnosis, overtreatment, and associated complications such as negative psychological effects, erectile dysfunction, or urine incontinence. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends against any routine PSA-based screening for prostate cancer; they recommend that decisions about PSA assessment in men aged 55–69 years who inquire about screening be made based on patient preference after having received information on potential risks and benefits. The American Urological Association recommends PSA testing on a case-by-case basis in men aged 45–69 years after shared decision-making based on individual preferences. PSA testing is not recommended in men < 40 years of age.

This patient is 60 years old and he has a family history of prostate cancer in a first-degree relative; a discussion about PSA screening would be warranted. Following the discussion, PSA levels should only be obtained if the patient expresses that he wants to proceed with the screening test.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-dose CT scan of the chest is recommended as a screening test for lung cancer in patients 50–80 years of age with a history of smoking (≥ 20 pack-years). Although this patient is 60 years old, he only has a 12 pack-year history. A low-dose CT scan would therefore not be indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is a diagnostic procedure for bladder cancer. Although this patient has risk factors for bladder cancer (works at a rubber factory, family history of bladder cancer, smokes cigarettes), a cystoscopy would only be indicated for the evaluation of gross hematuria or microscopic hematuria in patients > 35 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient's individual risk factors (e.g., family history, age, sex) should be taken into account when selecting the most appropriate next step in management.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressively worsening back pain that began about 2 months ago. It started as a dull pain that has now developed into a constant throbbing pain that makes falling asleep difficult. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen do not provide relief. The patient has not had any bowel incontinence, limb weakness, or paresthesias. He has metastatic prostate cancer with known metastasis to the sacrum and left ilium, but has had minimal pain related to these sites. He underwent bilateral orchiectomy two years ago, which was complicated by urinary incontinence. He currently takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is midline tenderness to palpation over the lower lumbar spine. MRI of the spine shows a new sclerotic lesion at the L5 vertebral body. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Zoledronic acid is a bisphosphonate that is used to prevent pathologic fractures in men with prostate cancer bone metastases and which may be useful as an adjunct therapy in this patient. However, studies have shown that zoledronic acid does not increase survival or delay the progression of cancer. This patient requires a treatment that targets his current symptoms and prolongs his survival.

B) INCORRECT:

Flutamide is primarily used as a medical castration agent to treat prostate cancer. As this patient has already undergone surgical castration via bilateral orchiectomy, flutamide would provide no further benefits. This patient requires treatment aimed towards his painful vertebral body metastasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal surgery is typically reserved for patients with vertebral body metastases who present with pathologic fractures or spinal cord compression. This patient does not have any clinical symptoms of spinal cord compression, such as bowel incontinence, limb weakness, and paresthesias. In addition, the MRI did not show any indication of a fracture or spinal compression. A more conservative therapy is indicated in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostatectomy is a targeted treatment used for localized prostate cancer that is not indicated in patients with metastatic disease. This patient requires treatment for his lower back pain secondary to vertebral bone metastases.

E) CORRECT:

Local radiation with external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) is the first-line treatment for patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer who have one or more bone metastases. In EBRT, a linear accelerator delivers carefully targeted high-energy beams from outside the body at the target tissue. The beams are delivered from different angles in order to spare the surrounding cells. Local radiation improves overall survival in patients with metastatic prostate cancer, provides symptomatic relief, and decreases the incidence of pathological fracture and spinal cord compression.

F) INCORRECT:

Denosumab can be used to prevent pathologic fractures in men with prostate cancer bone metastases and may be a useful adjunct therapy in this patient. However, studies have shown that denosumab does not increase survival or delay the progression of cancer. This patient requires a treatment that targets his current symptoms and prolongs his survival.
questions.hint: This patient has new lower back pain secondary to vertebral body metastasis. Treatment is aimed at slowing the growth of the sclerotic lesion and preventing complications such as spinal cord compression.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of urinary urgency, nocturia, and progressive pain in his lower back. The pain is worse at night and does not respond to ibuprofen. Rectal examination shows an enlarged, asymmetric prostate with a nodular surface. Prostate-specific antigen concentration is 11 ng/ml (N < 4). A biopsy of the prostate shows a high-grade adenocarcinoma. A CT scan of the pelvis shows multiple osteoblastic lesions of the lumbar spine. The patient is started on a drug that competes with androgens for interaction with the testosterone receptors. Treatment with which of the following drugs was most likely initiated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

GnRH agonists such as leuprolide are commonly used for medical androgen deprivation therapy in the initial treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. When administered continuously, GnRH agonists cause downregulation of the GnRH receptor in the pituitary, which reduces the secretion of gonadotropins (FSH, LH), thereby decreasing the production of androgens in the testes. GnRH agonists do not, however, influence the interaction between androgens and their receptors.

B) CORRECT:

Flutamide is a nonsteroidal competitive inhibitor for the binding of dihydrotestosterone and testosterone to the androgen receptor (i.e., an antiandrogen). The inhibition of androgen receptor stimulation prevents the growth of prostate cancer and its metastases. While antiandrogen monotherapy is an option for androgen deprivation therapy of metastatic prostate cancer, flutamide is most commonly used in combination with GnRH agonists (combined androgen blockade). The simultaneous administration of both drugs prevents the worsening of symptoms (e.g., bladder obstruction, bone pain) that may occur due to a transient rise in testosterone during initial treatment with GnRH agonists.

C) INCORRECT:

Degarelix, a GnRH antagonist, binds to GnRH receptors on pituitary gonadotropin-producing cells, immediately suppressing testosterone production. As opposed to GnRH agonists, GnRH antagonists are not associated with an initial disease flare, so they can be used as an alternative androgen deprivation therapy for metastatic prostate cancer. However, they do not influence the interaction between androgens and their receptors.

D) INCORRECT:

Docetaxel is a chemotherapeutic agent that stabilizes polymerized microtubules of the mitotic spindle during anaphase, thereby interfering with mitosis. Docetaxel can be used in combination with androgen deprivation therapy (e.g., GnRH agonists) for the initial treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. However, it does not influence the interaction between androgens and their receptors.

E) INCORRECT:

Finasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. This drug is primarily used in the treatment of benign prostate hyperplasia and androgenic alopecia. Finasteride is not indicated for the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer and it does not influence the interaction between androgens and their receptors.

F) INCORRECT:

Abiraterone, a CYP17 inhibitor, decreases the formation of testosterone precursors, which reduces the synthesis of androgens in the testes, adrenal glands, and (cancerous) prostate tissue. Abiraterone can be used in combination with prednisone in the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. However, it does not influence the interaction between androgens and their receptors.
questions.hint: The described drug is usually used as adjunctive treatment to gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (GnRH agonists) in order to prevent an initial testosterone flare-up.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening lower back pain for 6 weeks. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and that it sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has noticed a weakened urinary stream. He has not seen any blood in his urine. His only daily medication is ibuprofen, which does not provide adequate pain relief. Examination shows no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacute lower back pain worsened by palpation is a typical manifestation of a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). However, SEA is commonly associated with further symptoms, such as fever, malaise, and, eventually, neurologic deficits (secondary to spinal cord compression). Moreover, this patient has no risk factors for this condition (e.g., IV drug use, recent invasive spinal procedures, immunosuppression). While SEA can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Lack of improvement after 6 weeks of therapy with NSAIDs should further raise suspicion for a nonmuscular cause of the pain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pelvic pain and diarrhea. During this time, he has also had a sudden, strong urge to empty his bowels on a number of occasions. He describes his stool as "light-colored" and "jelly-like." He has not had rectal bleeding. Over the past 4 months, he has had two urinary tract infections that were successfully treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and cefpodoxime, respectively. One month ago, he was diagnosed with intermediate-risk localized prostate cancer, for which he underwent brachytherapy. The patient is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with a male partner and has never traveled outside the US. His only medication is over-the-counter ibuprofen for his pelvic pain. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 106/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen. Rectal examination is painful; there is oozing of mucous-covered stool. Serum prostate-specific antigen concentration is 2.12 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial invasion of the colon (e.g., by Campylobacter jejuni) causes infectious colitis (IC), which can manifest with diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, fecal urgency, and tenesmus. Receptive anal or oral-anal sex is a risk factor for the transmission of bacterial pathogens. However, bacterial IC typically causes acute, self-limiting diarrhea rather than progressively worsening, persistent diarrhea. Moreover, bacterial IC is usually associated with bloody diarrhea and fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxin-mediated inflammation of the colon is the pathomechanism of Clostridioides difficile colitis. This condition can also manifest with lower abdominal pain, fecal urgency, and nonbloody diarrhea and most commonly occurs following antibiotic treatment (e.g., with cephalosporins). However, C. difficile colitis is typically associated with watery and foul-smelling diarrhea and fever. Mucus in stool and a painful rectal examination are not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Obliteration of colonic vessels is the pathomechanism of chronic radiation proctopathy, a type of chronic radiation injury that can manifest with rectal pain as well as fecal urgency following radiation therapy to the pelvis. However, chronic radiation proctopathy is typically associated with constipation (due to fibrosis of the colonic wall) rather than diarrhea. Most importantly, this condition is a late complication of radiation therapy, occuring > 3 months after exposure.

D) CORRECT:

Radiation damage to the rectal mucosa causes acute radiation proctitis (ARP), which manifests with pelvic and rectal pain, mucus in diarrhea, tenesmus, and/or fecal urgency within 3 months of radiation therapy. The risk of ARP depends on the radiation dose to the rectum and how much of the rectum receives radiation. Evaluation of patients with suspected ARP consists of a detailed history, laboratory tests with stool cultures to exclude infection, and, if there is diagnostic uncertainty, endoscopy with biopsies. Supportive treatment (e.g., antidiarrheal therapy, hydration) is usually sufficient.

'Direct tissue damage caused by single or multiple doses of radiation → inflammation', 'Pelvic radiation treatment (most commonly for anal, prostate, rectal, cervical, and bladder cancers'

E) INCORRECT:

Local spread of prostate cancer cells into the rectum can cause rectal pain, diarrhea, fecal urgency, and tenesmus. This patient, however, was diagnosed with localized prostate cancer and underwent brachytherapy, which is considered a definitive treatment. Moreover, his prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is currently within the reference range, whereas a recent cancer spread or metastasis into the rectum would lead to a significant increase in the PSA level.
questions.hint: Pelvic and rectal pain, diarrhea, mucus discharge, and fecal urgency suggest radiation proctitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty urinating. He says that his urine stream has become weaker, and that for the past 6 weeks, he has woken up 2–3 times every night to urinate. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows an asymmetrically enlarged and firm prostate with a nodular surface. Prostate-specific antigen concentration is 10.5 ng/mL (N < 4). Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. A transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy specimen shows an adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5). MRI of the prostate shows extraprostatic extension of the tumor into the seminal vesicles. After explaining the diagnosis to the patient, he states that he does not want to undergo surgical treatment. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is associated with which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hematuria and dysuria are potential adverse effects of radiation therapy. They occur because radiation therapy can damage the cells of the bladder wall, which can lead to cystitis. While radiation therapy can be used as adjunctive therapy in patients with locally advanced prostate cancer, the primary treatment is ADT, which is not associated with hematuria or dysuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Hair loss and gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms (e.g., diarrhea) are common adverse effects of chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., docetaxel), as these agents often affect rapidly multiplying cells (e.g., cells in the GI tract and hair follicles). While chemotherapy can be used as adjunctive therapy in patients with metastatic prostate cancer, it is not recommended for nonmetastatic disease. This patient should be treated with ADT, which is not associated with hair loss or GI symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Sexual dysfunction (e.g., decreased libido, erectile dysfunction) and changes in body image (e.g., gynecomastia, weight gain, decreased penile and testicular size) are common adverse effects of ADT, as ADT decreases testosterone production. Other adverse effects of decreased androgen production with ADT include changes in body composition (increased body fat, decreased muscle mass); increased risk of osteoporosis and fractures as a result of reduced bone density; and cognitive dysfunction.

Androgen synthesis inhibitors, androgen receptor antagonists, and radiation therapy can be used as adjunctive therapy in locally advanced and metastatic prostate cancer. Chemotherapy (e.g., docetaxel) can be used as adjunctive therapy in metastatic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Pancytopenia is a typical adverse effect of chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., docetaxel), as these agents often affect rapidly multiplying cells (e.g., cells in the bone marrow). While chemotherapy can be used as adjunctive therapy in patients with metastatic prostate cancer, it is not recommended for nonmetastatic disease. This patient should be treated with ADT, which can cause anemia as a result of decreased erythropoiesis, but is not associated with leukopenia or thrombocytopenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertension and hypokalemia are adverse effects of androgen synthesis inhibitors. They occur because androgen synthesis inhibitors increase ACTH levels, resulting in increased mineralocorticoid production and consequent potassium excretion and sodium reabsorption. While androgen synthesis inhibitors can be used as adjunctive therapy in patients with locally advanced prostate cancer, the primary treatment is ADT, which is not associated with hypertension or hypokalemia.
questions.hint: The most appropriate treatment for metastatic or locally advanced prostate cancer is androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) with either medical castration (e.g., using a gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist) or surgical castration (i.e., bilateral orchiectomy).

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, he underwent an ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy after a nontender, firm prostate nodule was found on digital rectal examination. The results of the biopsy disclosed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, and radiographic imaging showed no evidence of distant metastasis. The patient subsequently underwent a radical prostatectomy for localized prostate cancer. Since surgery, he has had mild erectile dysfunction but otherwise feels well. He has hypertension well controlled with ramipril. Family history is remarkable for metastatic lung cancer in his father. He lives with his wife. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is concerned about potential recurrence of his prostate cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to monitor for disease recurrence in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone scintigraphy is used to detect bone metastases in patients with prostate cancer. After definitive treatment, this modality is only indicated in symptomatic patients (e.g., those with pain in the lumbosacral spine) and is not used to screen for disease recurrence in asymptomatic patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasonography has low sensitivity and specificity in identifying prostate cancer and, therefore, is predominantly used to localize the prostate before obtaining biopsies. This modality is not routinely indicated for monitoring disease recurrence.

C) CORRECT:

Serial serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurements are used to monitor prostate cancer recurrence after definitive treatment. After successful radical prostatectomy, PSA should decrease to undetectable levels. Any measurable PSA level indicates biochemical recurrence and warrants further diagnostic testing (e.g., with pelvic MRI). In addition to PSA measurements, annual digital rectal examination should be performed to monitor for prostate cancer recurrence and rectal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Although an MRI of the prostate can be used to detect prostate cancer, this modality is only indicated after other tests have yielded a positive result when monitoring for disease recurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

Urine prostate cancer antigen 3 levels is being investigated as an adjunctive test to determine the need for prostate biopsy in patients with elevated PSA levels. However, this test is not routinely performed and is not used to monitor for disease recurrence.
questions.hint: After radical prostatectomy, no prostatic tissue remains in the body.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man reports fecal urgency, tenesmus, and occasional bloody stools that began a few months ago. He also notes recent onset of fatigue.
His medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and localized prostate cancer for which he received external-beam radiotherapy 8 years ago. His most recent prostate-specific antigen level, measured 2 months ago, was undetectable at <0.1 ng/mL (reference range, 0–4.0 ng/mL).
On physical examination, he is afebrile, and his abdomen is soft and nontender without rebound or guarding. His blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 90 beats per minute. A rectal examination reveals bright red blood but no visible external hemorrhoids or palpable masses.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4500
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.2
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
29.8
41–53


Platelet count (per mm3)
187,000
150,000–350,000


A coagulation panel is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recurrent invasive prostate cancer is unlikely in this patient, given his recent undetectable prostate-specific antigen level.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic radiation proctitis is one of the most common toxicities of radiation therapy for prostate cancer and can occur any time (even decades) after radiation exposure. Acute radiation proctitis refers to rectal bleeding that occurs during radiation treatment or within 6 weeks; it can take months to resolve. Both acute and chronic radiation proctitis have features of tenesmus and may cause rectal bleeding. Endoscopic examination shows friable mucosa, with biopsies differentiating radiation proctitis from infectious causes or inflammatory bowel disease. Treatment can consist of surveillance until resolution if the symptoms are mild. Other treatment options include glucocorticoid suppositories or enemas and argon plasma coagulation.

Key learning point: Radiotherapy for prostate cancer can lead to delayed bowel injury known as chronic radiation proctitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory bowel disease is an exclusion criterion for radiation treatment and would be unlikely to manifest in an older patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Internal hemorrhoids could cause bleeding, but are not likely to cause tenesmus and significant anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Anal fissure could cause pain, but is not likely to cause tenesmus and significant anemia.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man is hospitalized with symptoms of a urinary tract infection. He reports a 6-month history of progressive urinary frequency, nocturia, and inability to fully void.
His history is significant for hypertension, a three-vessel coronary-artery bypass graft surgery, and localized prostate cancer (Gleason score, 7), which has been monitored by active surveillance. His prostate-specific antigen level was 5.2 ng/mL six months ago and is now 14.3 ng/mL (reference range, 0–4.0). Imaging shows local progression, and a digital rectal examination reveals palpable disease on one half of the prostate, making the clinical stage T2b.
Before this hospitalization, the patient was able to complete all his activities of daily living and walked 20 minutes daily. His heart disease has been well controlled with diet, exercise, and appropriate cardiac medications. He is adamant about not undergoing a surgical procedure because of friends who have had urinary incontinence after prostate surgery.
After treatment for the urinary tract infection, what other therapy is warranted?

choices.text: Radiation therapy with consideration for androgen-deprivation therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expectant management or active surveillance is an appropriate initial strategy for patients who have prostate cancer and a life expectancy of <10 years. However, once progression occurs, there are several options for management, including radiation therapy, transurethral resection of the prostate, and hormonal therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic chemotherapy, such as single-agent docetaxel, should be reserved for patients with castration-resistant metastatic prostate cancer, except when studied in clinical trials.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has a life expectancy of 3 to 6 years, given his advanced age and progressive prostate cancer. Expectant management or active surveillance is an appropriate initial strategy for patients who have prostate cancer and a life expectancy of <10 years. However, once progression occurs, there are several options for management, including radiation therapy, transurethral resection of the prostate, and hormonal therapy.

Radiation therapy is often favored for older patients. Complications include urethral or rectal irritation or bleeding in the short term — and hemorrhagic cystitis or secondary cancers of the bladder in the longer term. However, radiation therapy is less invasive than radical prostatectomy, which is associated with a 10% risk of long-term incontinence and a >50% risk of permanent erectile dysfunction in patients who are sexually active before surgery. It should be noted that the incidence of these adverse events is often reduced at high-volume centers with well-selected patients — and that radiation therapy can also contribute to erectile dysfunction, with 5-year rates similar to those seen with surgery. Observational data suggest that long-term disease control achieved with contemporary radiation therapy is similar to that achieved with radical prostatectomy.

Androgen-deprivation therapy can be considered as an adjunct to radiation therapy to allow for better, more rapid control of local symptoms, but alone, it would not provide sufficient control of disease. Risks of this therapy include cardiac disease and symptoms associated with androgen deprivation.

Key learning point: The most effective management option for symptomatic progressive prostate cancer in an older man with a life expectancy of <10 years who refuses or has a contraindication to surgery is radiation therapy with consideration for androgen-deprivation therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Hospice referral is appropriate for patients with a life expectancy of <6 months, which is unlikely in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Androgen-deprivation therapy can be considered as an adjunct to radiation therapy to allow for better, more rapid control of local symptoms, but alone, it would not provide sufficient control of disease. Risks of this therapy include cardiac disease and symptoms associated with androgen deprivation.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man presents with low back pain that began abruptly 2 days ago. Five years ago, he underwent prostatectomy for prostate cancer and, for the past year, has received a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone agonist to treat recurrent elevations in prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels.
Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the low back, with no associated leg weakness on neurologic examination. His last PSA level, measured one week ago, was stable at 1.0 ng/mL (reference range, 0–4.0). A nuclear bone scan 2 weeks ago was negative. He has no urinary or stool incontinence.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Undetected bone metastases causing pathologic fracture

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s low back pain is likely due to an osteoporotic fracture related to the androgen-deprivation therapy he has been receiving. Such therapy is associated with reductions in bone mineral density that can occur as early as the first 6 to 12 months of treatment. This effect is of particular concern among men with prostate cancer, who are often older.

Men should undergo dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry before starting androgen-deprivation therapy and then routinely throughout treatment. They should also implement lifestyle modifications such as calcium and vitamin D supplementation and increased weight-bearing exercise. Bisphosphonates have been shown to increase bone mineral density, but their effect on fracture risk is still being investigated.

Key learning point: Patients receiving androgen-deprivation therapy for prostate cancer should be monitored for osteopenia and osteoporosis-related complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Cord compression and disc herniation are unlikely in a patient without neurologic symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Although prostate cancer does metastasize to bones, the recent negative bone scan rules out bone metastases as a cause of fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Although osteoarthritis is possible in this patient, it would not cause acute onset of symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Cord compression and disc herniation are unlikely in a patient without neurologic symptoms.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man reports a 10-month history of progressive dyspnea with exertion and fatigue. His medical history is significant for localized prostate adenocarcinoma diagnosed 10 years ago for which he received radiotherapy followed by 4 months of androgen-deprivation therapy; after treatment, his prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level became undetectable. His PSA and digital rectal exams have remained normal during subsequent surveillance visits. He does not have any chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.
On examination, he appears fatigued but is awake and responding appropriately to questioning. He is in no acute distress. His conjunctivae are pale.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin level of 8.7 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5) and a mean corpuscular volume of 72 μm3 (80–100). His platelet and leukocyte counts are within normal limits. His iron saturation is low. His PSA level is undetectable. A fecal occult-blood test is weakly positive. A recent chest radiograph is normal.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A tagged red-cell nuclear scan requires active bleeding at a rate of up to 0.5 mL/minute to be diagnostic and is relatively insensitive compared with other mechanisms for establishing the cause of gastrointestinal bleeding. In this patient, whose history is consistent with a slow, chronic blood-loss anemia, a tagged red-cell scan is unlikely to be able to identify the source of bleeding.

B) CORRECT:

A patient with signs and symptoms of iron-deficiency anemia, including a positive fecal occult-blood test, should have a careful evaluation for gastrointestinal causes of blood loss. A history of radiation treatment for prostate cancer increases the risk for radiation-associated proctitis, which can happen acutely (within 6 weeks of radiation therapy, causing tenesmus and diarrhea) or much later (from 9–12 months after radiation treatment to several decades later, causing strictures and bleeding due to chronic ischemia). In patients with symptomatic anemia, the recommended initial evaluation is colonoscopy. Signs of chronic radiation ischemia and injury include friability, pallor, and telangiectasias.

Key learning point: In a patient with a history of prostate cancer treated with pelvic radiation who develops microcytic anemia and fatigue and has a positive fecal occult-blood test, the best diagnostic test is colonoscopy to evaluate for potential lower gastrointestinal sources of blood loss, including radiation-induced proctitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy would be used to evaluate for bleeding from an upper gastrointestinal source, which would cause hematemesis or melena. However, given the lack of upper gastrointestinal symptoms and the risk for radiation proctitis, the best initial evaluation would be a colonoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging tests, such as positron emission tomography, are not appropriate to diagnose radiation proctitis, but they may be beneficial to evaluate for a second occult malignancy or alternative diagnosis if sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is unrevealing.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging tests, such as CT is not appropriate to diagnose radiation proctitis, but they may be beneficial to evaluate for a second occult malignancy or alternative diagnosis if sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is unrevealing.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports a rather rapidly developing 4-month history of difficulty initiating a urinary stream when he feels the urge to urinate. The stream is typically weak and intermittent, with dribbling at the end of urination and a sense of incomplete emptying. The patient also notes that he wakes up 3 to 4 times per night to urinate. For the past month, he has also had intermittent blood in his semen.
His medical history includes well-controlled hypertension on lisinopril for 15 years. He is a nonsmoker and walks briskly 5 miles daily.
Digital rectal examination reveals a smooth, enlarged, nontender prostate without nodularity.
Urinalysis is normal. The serum creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3).
In addition to completing a voiding diary, which one of the following initial interventions is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology testing may be considered in selected patients with unexplained hematuria, but it is not indicated in a patient with lower urinary tract symptoms and a normal urinalysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasound and cystoscopy are not appropriate first-line tests for patients whose symptoms likely represent benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, these tests may eventually be indicated if subsequent evaluation or poor response to treatment suggests a need to exclude prostate cancer or bladder cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasound and cystoscopy are not appropriate first-line tests for patients whose symptoms likely represent benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, these tests may eventually be indicated if subsequent evaluation or poor response to treatment suggests a need to exclude prostate cancer or bladder cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the patient’s testosterone level is unnecessary when symptoms suggesting hypogonadism are absent.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has bothersome lower urinary tract symptoms, which suggests the need for further evaluation. The symptoms of a weak stream, dribbling, and incomplete emptying are considered obstructive symptoms, whereas the frequency, nocturia, and urgency are considered storage or irritative symptoms. Both types of symptoms are common with benign prostatic hyperplasia. Hematospermia usually results from benign causes but is occasionally a manifestation of prostate cancer. This patient has an enlarged prostate with no nodules; the normal urinalysis excludes urinary tract infection as a cause of his symptoms.

Early prostate cancer itself will not usually produce symptoms of frequency, urgency, hesitance, terminal dribbling, or overactive bladder. Most prostate tumors originate in the peripheral zones of the prostate gland distant from the urethra. Although benign prostatic hyperplasia is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms, it is reasonable to perform prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing to help guide further decision-making in a patient with relatively recent-onset lower urinary tract symptoms and hematospermia. Some authorities also recommend measurement of postvoid residual, preferably by an ultrasound bladder scan.

Key learning point: Although a prostate-specific antigen level is not needed in patients presenting with classic lower urinary tract symptoms from benign prostatic hyperplasia, it should be considered in patients who have unusual features such as rapid onset of symptoms or hematospermia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to establish primary care after moving from a different state. He says he has lost 9 kg during the past 3 months because of the stress of moving. He has benign prostatic hypertrophy and reports urinary frequency and nocturia for the past 5 years, as well as some pelvic discomfort. His other medical conditions include hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and a history of gonococcal urethritis. His current medications are tamsulosin, amlodipine, and metformin.
He has a blood pressure of 112/72 mm Hg, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and a temperature of 36.9°C. He weighs 62 kg (BMI, 26.3). Examinations of the heart, lungs, and abdomen are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate with an asymmetrical area of firm induration in the left lobe.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value last year
Patient valuetoday
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5
11.5
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7000
11,000
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
300,000
250,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
1.1
0.8–1.3


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
4.6
5.0
0.5–4.7


Prostate-specific antigen (ng/mL)
6.5
6.2
0–4.0


Routine urinalysis and microscopy are within normal limits.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most important for this patient?

choices.text: Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae
CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patient who has chronic urinary symptoms, unintentional weight loss, and an abnormal prostate examination should undergo evaluation for prostate cancer, even if his prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level has been stable (as in this case). Transrectal prostate biopsy is the preferred diagnostic test for prostate cancer.

Key learning point: Older men with findings suggestive of prostate cancer should undergo evaluation with transrectal prostate biopsy regardless of prostate-specific antigen level.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis or endorectal coil MRI may be indicated for staging once prostate cancer has been diagnosed, but neither test is sensitive enough to be included in the initial workup for prostate cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and urine culture after prostatic massage are used to evaluate for chronic prostatitis. This condition usually manifests with chronic voiding symptoms and perineal or pelvic pain, but it would not explain this patient’s weight loss and asymmetrical prostate induration.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis or endorectal coil MRI may be indicated for staging once prostate cancer has been diagnosed, but neither test is sensitive enough to be included in the initial workup for prostate cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and urine culture after prostatic massage are used to evaluate for chronic prostatitis. This condition usually manifests with chronic voiding symptoms and perineal or pelvic pain, but it would not explain this patient’s weight loss and asymmetrical prostate induration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to establish primary care after moving from a different state. He says he has lost 9-kg (20-lb) during the past 3 months because of the stress of moving. He has benign prostatic hypertrophy and reports urinary frequency and nocturia for the past 5 years, as well as some pelvic discomfort. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate with an asymmetrical area of firm induration in the left lobe. Laboratory studies show anemia. Prostate-specific antigen is 6.2 ng/mL (N = 0–4.0). Urinalysis and microscopy are within normal limits. Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most important for this patient?

choices.text: Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae
CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patient who has chronic urinary symptoms, unintentional weight loss, and an abnormal prostate examination should undergo evaluation for prostate cancer, even if his prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level has been stable (as in this case). Transrectal prostate biopsy is the preferred diagnostic test for prostate cancer.

Key learning point: Older men with findings suggestive of prostate cancer should undergo evaluation with transrectal prostate biopsy regardless of prostate-specific antigen level.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis or endorectal coil MRI may be indicated for staging once prostate cancer has been diagnosed, but neither test is sensitive enough to be included in the initial workup for prostate cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and urine culture after prostatic massage are used to evaluate for chronic prostatitis. This condition usually manifests with chronic voiding symptoms and perineal or pelvic pain, but it would not explain this patient’s weight loss and asymmetrical prostate induration.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis or endorectal coil MRI may be indicated for staging once prostate cancer has been diagnosed, but neither test is sensitive enough to be included in the initial workup for prostate cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and urine culture after prostatic massage are used to evaluate for chronic prostatitis. This condition usually manifests with chronic voiding symptoms and perineal or pelvic pain, but it would not explain this patient’s weight loss and asymmetrical prostate induration.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of worsening lower back pain for 6 weeks. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and that it sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has noticed a weakened urinary stream. Examination shows no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. Six years ago, he underwent a colonoscopy, which was unremarkable. He has no history of serious illness. His father died of bladder carcinoma at the age of 55 years and his brother was diagnosed with prostate cancer at the age of 61 years. The patient works at a rubber factory. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 12 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks what additional health maintenance measures he should consider at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the provider?

choices.text: Discuss prostate-specific antigen assessment with the patient
Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology can be used in the workup for urothelial cancer. While this patient has risk factors for bladder cancer (works at a rubber factory, family history of bladder cancer, smokes cigarettes), urine cytology is not used for routine screening of bladder cancer because of its low sensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

The US Preventative Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 6 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

C) CORRECT:

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement may be considered as part of the screening process for prostate cancer, a common malignancy that is often asymptomatic in the initial stages. Current screening guidelines for prostate-specific antigen testing are controversial. The use of PSA as a screening marker is constantly questioned because of potential overdiagnosis, overtreatment, and associated complications such as negative psychological effects, erectile dysfunction, or urine incontinence. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends against any routine PSA-based screening for prostate cancer; they recommend that decisions about PSA assessment in men aged 55–69 years who inquire about screening be made based on patient preference after having received information on potential risks and benefits. The American Urological Association recommends PSA testing on a case-by-case basis in men aged 45–69 years after shared decision-making based on individual preferences. PSA testing is not recommended in men < 40 years of age.

This patient is 60 years old and he has a family history of prostate cancer in a first-degree relative; a discussion about PSA screening would be warranted. Following the discussion, PSA levels should only be obtained if the patient expresses that he wants to proceed with the screening test.

Key learning point: For men aged 55–69, especially with a family history of prostate cancer, shared decision-making about prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening is recommended to weigh potential benefits and risks.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-dose CT scan of the chest is recommended as a screening test for lung cancer in patients 50–80 years of age with a history of smoking (≥ 20 pack-years). Although this patient is 60 years old, he only has a 12 pack-year history. A low-dose CT scan would therefore not be indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is a diagnostic procedure for bladder cancer. Although this patient has risk factors for bladder cancer (works at a rubber factory, family history of bladder cancer, smokes cigarettes), a cystoscopy would only be indicated for the evaluation of gross hematuria or microscopic hematuria in patients > 35 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient's individual risk factors (e.g., family history, age, sex) should be taken into account when selecting the most appropriate next step in management.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with prostate cancer has progressive low back pain and an elevated alkaline phosphatase. Imaging shows sclerotic lesions in the lumbar vertebrae. What best explains this metastatic pattern?

choices.text: Retrograde lymphatic flow from the pelvis
Venous spread via a valveless vertebral network
Local extension through the prostatic capsule
Arterial embolization via the internal iliac system

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lymphatic spread in prostate cancer typically affects regional lymph nodes, not vertebral bodies. The lumbar vertebrae's sclerotic lesions and elevated alkaline phosphatase suggest osteoblastic activity, consistent with venous, not lymphatic, dissemination. The valveless venous network, not lymphatics, facilitates retrograde flow to the vertebrae.

B) CORRECT:

Prostate cancer metastasizes to the skeleton primarily through Batson’s plexus, a valveless vertebral venous network connecting the prostatic venous plexus to the lumbar vertebral system. This network allows bidirectional blood flow, bypassing the lungs and facilitating direct seeding of tumor cells in the axial skeleton. The sclerotic lesions seen on imaging are due to an osteoblastic response, and elevated alkaline phosphatase indicates increased bone turnover. This venous dissemination explains the lumbar vertebrae's involvement in prostate cancer metastasis.

Key learning point: The first site for venous spread of prostate cancer is typically the bone, facilitated by Batson's plexus, a network of valveless veins connecting the pelvic and vertebral venous systems.

C) INCORRECT:

Local extension through the prostatic capsule involves direct invasion of nearby structures, such as the seminal vesicles or bladder. This process does not account for distant sclerotic lesions in the lumbar vertebrae, which suggest hematogenous spread. Elevated alkaline phosphatase and vertebral involvement indicate osteoblastic activity at distant sites, inconsistent with local extension.

D) INCORRECT:

Arterial embolization is not the typical route for prostate cancer metastasis to the lumbar vertebrae. The internal iliac arteries supply pelvic organs, but prostate cancer spreads via Batson’s plexus, a valveless venous network. This venous route allows retrograde flow to the lumbar spine, leading to sclerotic lesions and elevated alkaline phosphatase.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-week history of worsening lower back pain. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has also noticed a weakened urinary stream. On examination, there are no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength and sensation are normal bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his back pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

Key learning point: In older adults, persistent or progressive back pain—especially with nocturnal symptoms or urinary changes—should raise suspicion for malignancy, such as metastatic prostate cancer to the spine.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of progressive urinary hesitancy and a 12-hour history of complete inability to void. He reports no fever or dysuria. A Foley catheter is successfully placed, draining 800 mL of clear urine. Digital rectal examination shows a hard, irregular, nontender mass involving both lobes of the prostate with obliteration of the median sulcus. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe tamsulosin and schedule outpatient follow-up
Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Obtain serum prostate-specific antigen and arrange urgent urology consultation
Administer empiric ciprofloxacin for bacterial prostatitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha-blockers such as tamsulosin are appropriate for benign prostatic hyperplasia symptoms, but the hard, irregular prostatic mass with bilateral involvement and obliteration of the median sulcus strongly suggests malignancy rather than benign enlargement.

B) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for prostate cancer, but this specialized procedure requires appropriate patient counseling and preparation and is performed by a urologist.

C) INCORRECT:

While cross-sectional imaging may eventually be needed for cancer staging, the immediate priority in the emergency department is obtaining prostate-specific antigen levels and arranging urgent urology consultation. Advanced imaging decisions should be made by the urologist based on the complete clinical picture.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of complete urinary retention and a hard, irregular prostatic mass with bilateral involvement and obliteration of the median sulcus strongly suggests locally advanced prostate cancer, warranting urgent urology referral. Prostate-specific antigen testing provides important baseline information for the urologist.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial prostatitis typically manifests with fever, dysuria, and a tender, swollen prostate on examination. This patient has no fever or dysuria, and the prostate is hard and nontender on examination, which is characteristic of malignancy rather than infection.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his lower extremities and urinary incontinence for the past 3 weeks. Over the past 2 months, he has also had increasing back pain. Physical examination shows an unsteady gait. Muscle strength is decreased in both lower extremities. Sensation to pain, temperature, and position sense is absent in the buttocks, perineum, and lower extremities. Ankle clonus is present. An x-ray of the spine shows multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated prostate-specific antigen in the serum
Palpable thyroid nodule on neck examination
Bence Jones protein in the urine
Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen in the serum
Irregular, asymmetric mole on skin examination

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are typically found in patients with prostate cancer but can also be seen in benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostatitis. This patient's age, as well as his clinical and radiological findings, which strongly suggest spinal cord compression due to metastatic lesions of the vertebrae, indicate metastatic prostate cancer. Prostate cancer is one of the most common cancers and also the most common cause of bone metastases in men. It mostly affects older men (average age of onset is 66 years of age).

B) INCORRECT:

A palpable thyroid nodule would be concerning for thyroid cancer. Although thyroid cancer can also metastasize to the bone, it typically manifests with osteolytic lesions rather than the osteoblastic ones seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Bence Jones protein in the urine would be suggestive of multiple myeloma, which can also cause spinal cord compression, as seen in this patient. However, multiple myeloma typically causes osteolytic lesions rather than osteoblastic ones. Additionally, a patient with multiple myeloma would most likely present with other clinical features such as anemia, increased susceptibility to infections, and/or hypercalcemia.

D) INCORRECT:

An elevated carcinoembryonic antigen can be seen in several different cancers but is especially associated with pancreatic cancer and colon cancer. Although colon cancer can metastasize to the bones and present with osteoblastic metastases, this is not a frequent finding (seen in only 5–10% of cases of advanced colorectal cancer). Instead, the liver and lungs are the most common sites of metastases for both pancreatic and colorectal carcinoma. The absence of typical symptoms associated with colorectal cancer, such as a change in bowel habits, melena or hematochezia, signs of anemia, and/or weight loss, also makes colon cancer less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

An irregular, asymmetric mole would be concerning for malignant melanoma. Although malignant melanoma may also rarely manifest with bone metastases, this disease typically causes osteolytic lesions rather than the osteoblastic ones seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The presence of back pain, urinary incontinence, muscle weakness, and decreased sensation in the lower extremities is consistent with spinal cord compression. Multiple sclerotic lesions on x-ray suggest osteoblastic metastases.
